subtitle: Thinking Allowed Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be examining the life and work of the Nobel laureate poet William Butler
Yeats with a particular focus on his interest in magic.
My guest is my good friend James Tunney.
He is author of The Mystical Accord, Sutras to
Suit Our Times, Lines for Spiritual Evolution,
The Mystery of the Trapped Light, Mystical
Thoughts in the Dark Age of Scientism, Empire
the Dispiriting Conspiracy and Inevitable
Tyranny of Scientocracy, Tech Bondage, Slavery
of the Human Spirit, Human Entrance to Transhumanism,
Machine Merger and the End of Humanity.
He's also written two dystopian novels, Blue
Lies September and Ireland, I Don't Recognize
Who She Is.
His most recent book is Plantation of the Automatons.
James lives in Gothenburg, Sweden and now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome James.
It's a pleasure yet again to be with you.
Always a pleasure to talk to you, Jeffrey.
I'm looking forward to our conversation.
Now, I'm very excited about our conversation
today because I know many times across the
38 previous videos that we've done, Yeats has
come up as an important figure for worldwide
literary culture, for Irish culture, and in
particular because of his prolonged and dedicated
and deep interest in magic.
Well, yes, one of the problems with these
figures is they're so big that you don't know
where to start, but by concentrating on the
magic element, I think it may help some people
to understand the man who was known as a poet,
who won the Nobel Prize for his poetry, but
also was a playwright and a novelist, and he managed a theater as well, and he was a
senator. He was a statesman, so he was very involved in a lot of issues, but sometimes
this issue of his magic is forgotten or left
to decide by people who are not interested
in it and regard it as silly as W.H.
Auden seems to have done.
But he is a major figure, and every time one
digs a bit deeper, one finds some revealing
fact which connects him into the story and the great narrative.
When it comes to magic, I can think of it in two different contexts. One would be the
actual ceremonial operations of a magician, and I would summarize those by saying it's
an exercise in willpower. You want to achieve
a certain goal through magical will. On the
other hand, he seemed to be dedicated to a revival of the ancient Irish traditions
that included a magical worldview.
Yes. A very critical link between our previous
conversations, and especially about the Inklings,
is the motivation for his magic and the motivation
for his art. And in many senses, the magic
came before the poetry, before the medium.
So his magic is a critical worldview for him.
Occasionally he refers to it as mysticism,
but it's not, and he wouldn't make any claims
to that. So he's talking about magic. And the context of the origin of his magic was
very clear, that what he saw was, and particularly
through the person of his father, and he had
arguments with his father, kind of serious
rows with his father about his father's embrace
of science and rationalism to the exclusion of other worldviews. And he said to himself
that this made it difficult for him to believe
in his Christianity as it stood. Now, what
he was referring to was a kind of, he wasn't
deeply involved in Christianity, but that
was the context in which he was brought up as an Irish Protestant, no matter how low
the exposure was. But this growth of rationalism
and the scientific worldview after the theory
of evolution made it difficult for him to continue with those perspectives and those
worldviews. And he realized early on that
this scientific worldview, not mere science,
but scientism perhaps, was going to destroy
many of the traditional worldviews. And really
he set about trying to establish a new kind of universal religion, which was based on
recognition of spirituality and was for him through the medium of magic. So he had bold
ambitions in his mind. So in relation to magic, there's two streams. There's one,
the ceremonial magic, and he was heavily into
that because he wasn't very mystically inclined.
He needed technique in order to help him on his journey. And the second one was about
spirituality and spiritism, if you like. And
here, the great figure who was the source
of all the influence is Swedenborg. So
Swedenborg influences him indirectly at first,
through figures like Honoré de Balzac, the
French writer, and in particular through a book
that his father had read to him or told him
about, which was Louis Lambert, or Louis Lambert,
if you like. And this was a book that Balzac
wrote in his great series when he's trying to
make sense of what had happened in France after
the revolution. And it's about a mystical boy
who is entranced with Swedenborg. So indirectly,
that way Swedenborg comes in. And he's also,
when we think of the Lake Isle of Innisfree,
I will arise and go now and go to Innisfree,
and a small cabin built there of clay and wattles
made. That poem has a number of mystical elements,
but it also has similarities to Unwalden Pond.
So it links into the transcendentalism in the
United States, which was heavily influenced
by Swedenborg. And then he becomes entranced
with William Blake. So that brings him back to Swedenborg again. So Swedenborg is aware
of what's happening in psychic research. He's
aware of spiritism and Allan Kardec, and that's
got a root in Swedenborg. And he does write one
of the four major pieces he writes about magic
was Swedenborg, Mediums, and the Desolate Places
in 1914. So he shows his debt to Swedenborg.
But as well as that kind of spiritism,
spiritualism, and ceremonial magic, there's also
a realization that they had on the Protestant
gentry or ascendancy, as they call it, the upper
class, the ruling class in Ireland. They realized
through the translation at that stage in the 19th
century, particularly by people like Standish
O'Grady, I think 1878, he wrote a book on the
ancient Irish heroes. It made available a literature that had been in existence from
ancient times and was still in the minds of the
ordinary people. And it was a revelation because
here was an ancient literature made accessible.
And it was a heroic literature. So the idea of
the hero becomes very important for this magician.
And it's actually a base for a lot of the hero's
journey. If you look back at Joseph Campbell, it's
not just choice that he was influenced by. Yeats
was important. And in fact, one of the ambitions
that didn't come to fruition was Yeats' idea
of having a kind of magical center called the
Castle of Heroes in the center of Ireland.
And this was inspired as well at a time when he was going around with
Douglas Hyde, who became an Irish president. So
it's not a marginal activity. But he wanted to
establish a center. And he developed the
rituals. More and more information is coming out
about the nature of the rituals so we can actually
get access to the initiation procedures. So it was
a combination. But also he believed that the
peasants, as they would have called them, or the
ordinary people, had within their oral tradition
a magical worldview. And it was to them
that he would go with Lady Gregory in the west
of Ireland. His family lived between Dublin
and London, but also they have family in the west
of Ireland, Sligo. And he also has great contacts
with Galway. And when he went to the west of
Ireland, he talked to the people. And later he
studied it more significantly. And that gave
him access to the fairy lore. And through that
connection, when he went to lecture in America,
he inspired people like Evan Wentz, who came to
Ireland to study the fairy fate from Oxford and also Scotland as well. And subsequently
went on to do the Tibetan Book of the Dead. So that shows the cosmopolitan approach.
He was also influenced by the visit of Mohini
Chatterjee, who was a theosophist who came to
Dublin in 1885. And he informed him about the
nature of Indian thought, which was a central
piece of the architecture of his worldview for
all his life. And in fact, the last book that
he did was the 10 books of the Upanishads with
an Indian Swami. And they worked together on that
in Mallorca. So there's a number of different
currents. And it indicates that it was a
pragmatic worldview that incorporated a whole
range of views, because he realized that they
would have to fit in in order to combat this
force, which he identified with Thomas H. Huxley
and John Tyndall, who is less well known these
days, but he was a scientist from Ireland,
who was engaged in the usual suspects of study like crystallography,
as we've talked about before.
Now, you mentioned Lady Gregory as being an
important figure in his exploration of Irish
folklore. Can you tell me anything else about her?
She's an interesting figure. And she, they
become friendly. And he had a capacity, although
some people suggest he had poor relationships
with women, he had fantastic relationships with
a range of women that he he really respected
and learned from. And when he became a senator,
he advocated for women's rights at a time
when Ireland was getting a bit more provincial
in the context of divorce, and women's right to
work after they're married, he did and he opposed
a narrow view that they should have listened
to him at this stage. So he forms a very good
connection with her and she is, again, there's a
very feminine element to the spirituality he saw.
He was surrounded when he went to London as well
by a lot of very advanced esoteric spiritual
practitioners who, who are women, and Lady Gregory gave him access to the fairy tales.
There was other people of the same class who are doing so, for example,
Wilde's mother in Dublin was very interested
and wrote under a pen named Speranza, she wrote
about fairy tales, and she had, she had actually
been inspired by her visits to Sweden in relation
to the idea of strong female figures. So she was
she was she helped him in a number of endeavors,
not least giving him space at a time when he
was going through unrequited love. And she,
she also was involved in the establishment of
the Irish National Theatre, which became the
Abbey in 1904, that that Yates manages and uses as a platform for his own
theatre and for the theatre of other people,
including some of the individuals who would
lead the revolution in 1916. So she was a
significant figure in relation to recovering,
and that's an important word, this recovery that
we see in relation to Tolkien and this act of
recovery of an ancient, of an ancient way of
thinking, an ancient worldview. And they realized
as well, not only was there great wisdom there, but
it was disappearing, and it would be disappearing
with the with the kind of ripple effect from
the great technological concentration in London.
And the West of Ireland was in many ways, an
ancient society still, it was very underdeveloped,
very non-industrialized. And that meant that
in many ways, Ireland was 300 years before
behind the rest of Europe. The disadvantage of
that, you can say in an economic materialist
perspective is clear, but it's not a disadvantage
in a spiritual, in a spiritual term, because the
oral culture meant that they weren't spiritually
impoverished, like the denizens and citizens
of the of the metropolis. But Lady Gregory was one of many, many women around him
that was a big influence, and that this comes up again and again.
You also mentioned to me earlier that one of his first influences was an Irish mystic
about whom we've done a previous interview, A.E.
Russell. In fact, for viewers who are interested,
I'm going to link to our earlier interview about A.E. as he was known.
Yeah, I should say, of course, that Lady Gregory
was a great, did a lot of poetry herself and
translations and was a significant figure and
helped in that actual endeavor. So he meets,
his father followed a well-known path to penury by
leaving his legal career and becoming an artist.
So he didn't pursue his qualifications and he
became an artist. And art was very important in
the Yates household. His sisters were involved
in printing and a number of artistic crafts
activities. And John, his father was an artist and had a studio in Dublin.
So this is an important part in relation to the development of the mage or the magus,
because if we put an eye in front of the mage, we
have image and image is an important part of his
conception of magic. And in particular, he has a very important focus on symbols,
as we can talk about. But he meets A.E. Russell
at this art school and that leads to a fairly
long, long interaction between them around the ideas of spirituality and magic and the
ancient lore of Ireland. And they're both Protestants, but they both had a deep love,
affection for Ireland. And A.E. Russell directed
them more to the poetry away from being a painter,
perhaps. He had an influence in that perspective.
He was important for Yates in the number, so their
lives intertwined for a period. There was in most
of the endeavors that Yates did over a period of
time, A.E. Russell was there. He was involved
in the theater for a certain length of time.
But one of the interesting collaborations they
had was in relation to the development of a Celtic
mystery school. They wanted to create an order
based in Ireland, which would be a magical order
with the rights and procedures that existed in
other magical traditions. They wanted to restore
the Hibernian mysteries, I suppose. Steiner talks
about the Hibernian mysteries as being the last
mysteries that existed into the modern world. And
it was an important part in Steiner's worldview.
In the 1890s, when Yates got involved in ceremonial magic, he had a team around him
from the order he was in. And he also had access
to mystics outside. And what they sought to do
was to invoke and evoke ancient heroes, kings,
druids to advise them and to interact with them.
So he describes going with A.E. Russell into the
country, and the druids appeared before them.
And in the magic of the time, there is a practice
which is less well treated in the literature,
whereby figures are mentally or magically
projected before you. Now, this doesn't seem,
it's not always purely in the mind. There's great analysis of this. But it's more as
Terje Simonsen, who you had on your program,
talked in his book, it's more what's called in
Norwegian, a sink verving, a kind of sight twisting. So it's an idea of projection of
figures before. Now, that happens in magical
rituals. But this is a wider concept, as well as
some ability to enter into a territory. Now, this
would be in a mental way where the groups of them
went on a journey together into the mystic lands
back into ancient Ireland, and into the zones
where they could meet figures like Angus, for
example, figures like Oisín. So some of these
figures that you see in his poetry, were figures
that they're claiming to have actually met in this
magical way. So there's another level to the poetry
that's maybe hard for people to understand. And
when he was in London, he had met Samuel Mathers
at the British Museum, become involved in magic
over there. And one of the techniques that they
used a lot was the invocation of mental images
through the use of symbols. So there was an
actual practice using cards that they call tatvas.
And they also use talismans. So these would invoke
shared images, and they would use them to invoke
shared images, and they would enter into the
terrain. So this presents another possibility,
when we come to think about the Inklings and we've talked about and their worlds of
mythopoiesis. And of course, Yeats is engaging
mythopoiesis. But the idea that actually,
there is a kind of magical invocation of a fantasy
land, which are a land which in some way exists,
or is capable of being shared. But A.E. Russell was
an important collaborator who was excited by this
heroic phase and who saw that there was a counterpoint to the dying of the stagnation
within Christian culture, whereby it had been
reduced to adherence to rules without any general
spiritual growth. And also in a context where it
could be used to polarize in an Irish context.
So they were arguing always for an act of
spirituality. And Yeats wasn't interested in
passive spirituality or even passive suffering.
He wouldn't as an editor publish poems about the
First World War that he saw as merely about
passive suffering. It had to be something active
that you took ownership of. So yes, A.E.
Russell is an important part of many around him.
And you mentioned Samuel Mathers, who was the
founder or one of the founders of the Order of
the Golden Dawn, which was a magical order. And I certainly want to talk about Mathers
and the Golden Dawn. But actually, I understand
from our previous conversation that even prior to
his involvement with the Golden Dawn, he was
a close associate of Madame Blavatsky and the
Theosophical Movement and their inner esoteric circle.
That's right. And an important part in all this
is to remember that Ireland and India are in the
same constitutional arrangement in the British
Empire. So there's an Indian influence in Dublin
before we have the Californian influence later on. People forget about this context.
And there's a figure, Charles Johnson, who he
was friendly with, and he introduced him to
Theosophy at the start and Hermeticism. So
there's a Dublin Hermetic society that Yeats is
involved in. So around 1884, 1885, he's involved
with Charles Johnson and with A.E. Russell in
exploring Theosophy. And this becomes important.
And even later on, when he comes back to Dublin,
but in the same places that he would have studied
Theosophy or learned or met about Theosophy,
there is a famous story when Maud Gonne, the
woman he loved, but who was unrequited love,
essentially, she goes off to France. She has a
baby. The baby dies. And she comes back to Dublin.
She's distraught. And in Dublin, she asks A.E.
Russell and Yeats whether the child could be
reincarnated. And as a result, it's a very
strange story. As a result of their conversations,
she goes back to the man who fathered the first child, and they conceive a child.
She conceives a child in the place where the
other child was buried with the idea that the
child would be reincarnated. A very strange view.
But Theosophy was the connection. And then this
London-Dublin connection was very open. So it's
from Theosophy and Hermeticism. So there's a
Hermetic influence. But he was also interested
in ghosts. He had a lifelong interest in ghosts.
In 1913, as a member of the Dublin branch of
the Society for Psychical Research, he does a
presentation on Halloween on ghosts. And he offered
himself at this period to stay in haunted houses
when people were investigating them. So he was
a bit of a ghost hunter. And when he comes to
London, he also joins the Ghost Club, which was
an earlier endeavor of psychic research before the
Society was set up. And it was set up in, I think,
in 62 and has roots going back to the 1850s. So
this was an interesting reaction from the
intelligentsia, in some senses, to the scientific
worldview. So we have his interest there in Indian philosophy in Dublin, in Irish
ancient stories, ancient lore, in Hermeticism,
to whatever degree it's difficult to identify,
and Theosophy. So he comes to London, and he meets
Blavatsky as soon as he comes to London again
in 1887. And he joins the Theosophical Society as
part of the Esoteric Division. But now, despite
the fact that it was adverse publicity about
Blavatsky, he's impressed with her. So he believes
her presence is very impressive. And this is a
factor that I think people should bear in mind.
There are other factors that we can't really
judge unless we put them in the equation.
But he doesn't stay that long with them, because
he wants to do experiments. Despite the fact that
he is living in a dream world, he believes that
there should be empirical evidence. He believes
in experimentation. He had had an interest
in science early on, but he didn't like this
scientism. But because of that, he left. And then
that leads to him joining the Golden Dawn in 1890
after a meeting with Mathers at the British
Museum. And again, as we've talked about before,
in relation to Russell Square and the connection,
he lives just off Russell Square, and he goes to
the British Museum. But we can see that crossroads,
that clustering effect, which is important in
relation to the career of a number of people, as we've talked about.
Well, the Golden Dawn was a very influential,
magical order. They had a series of degrees.
They were, I suppose you could say, modeled to some extent on the Freemasons and on the
Rosicrucians.
Yes. There's really no magical order of this
period that doesn't have some connection to
Freemasonry. There's a real crossover, and there still is today. It's clear.
And that was no different in relation to the
Golden Dawn. The sources are quite diverse,
but it's in the Western magical tradition, and there's debate about the origins.
There's certainly a connection to Eliphaus
Levy in France, who, of course, is inspired by
Swedenborg as well. So that connection is there
as well. But there's a number of trends. One of
the most dominant is Kabbalah or Christian Kabbalah. But I mean, it's based on the
Kabbalah as developed various stages from
Spain through Italy, through the Renaissance.
And so when, for example, when Yeats is talking
about the rose, he's often talking about a very
unique symbol, a circular symbol, which has the
Hebrew alphabet and five petals and 17 petals.
And the Hebrew, you've talked before about Jane
Houston and her lectures and how important they
were for you. That same philosophy underpinned
the approach. So they were a very studious bunch.
So they informed themselves on Kabbalah and the
conception. So when we're talking about the tree,
for example, in his poetry, the symbols of the
tree in his poetry or the rose, they refer back
to other things like Rosicrucianism, as you've
said, although there's debates about the exact
nature and there's various historical ideas, the
ideas were part of the equation. But there's also
astrology and alchemy. It was very, very comprehensive attempt. And of course,
looking back in the Hermetic tradition to Egypt,
and Egypt was an important influence and Freemasonry
and the ideas and Freemasonry. And of course, it
was very clear and evident in the British Museum,
the links back to Egypt and the hieroglyphics and
the worldview. So when we're talking about some of
the symbols of birds and hawks, we can begin
to think of the work by people like Massey
on Egypt, and the ideas of the different ideas
of the soul in the Egyptian tradition. So it was
really a an ambitious, comprehensive attempt on
the outer order, they were in, they had to study
the theory. And as they moved into the inner
order, they, after they were initiated, they
concentrate on practical magic. Now, Yeats was always interested in practical magic,
although later he develops a very comprehensive
worldview, he was interested in practical magic
with all the talismans and all the symbols. So the symbols that he uses in his poetry
fall into a number of categories. But you can see
in a kind of binary way where we have a circular
form, feminine form, and a masculine form, we
would like a phallic form. And this is a binary,
a binary idea that seems to underpin his
thinking, so that we have a whole load of symbols,
like from the circle, the sun, the moon, the clock
face, a stone in a circular form or a pebble.
And on the in relation to the equivalent of the
one we have the tower, the spear, the sword,
the hourglass, and then he mixes them up later
on in relation to their interaction. So we have
these ideas, but these were reflecting magical
implements that they would have used directly
in their magical experiments. And he sought to
extrapolate from these ceremonial magic when he
was coming to design the Celtic orders, the mystery for the Celtic order.
One of the things that the Order of the Golden
Dawn is associated with, particularly in the
modern imagination these days, is the notorious
figure of Aleister Crowley, who was also involved
in the Golden Dawn. And I gather that he
and Yeats really didn't get along very well.
No. Yeats thought he was mad, and he had a
sense about him, and there was a real opposition
there. There seems to be an argument that Crowley was jealous of Yeats and that when
Yeats didn't appreciate his poetry, because of
course we have a similar pattern in relation to
Crowley, that he's a poet and a novelist and a painter and as well as a magician.
So he, and of course his name Aleister, was a made
up reference to Scotland to emphasize his Celtic
background. And later he comes to define himself
as an Irishman, although that's not true. But the
connection was important. It doesn't seem to be,
at least. I mean, there's a debate about some of
these issues. Like Yeats thought that Blake was
from an Irish background. He was convinced about
that, but most people don't think that. So it
comes to a head when there was a number of crises
for the Order of the Golden Dawn later on in
the century. And this involved a breakdown of
relationships, documents being released that
shouldn't have been released, secrets being
disclosed, and some figures coming in and
associating themselves with the Order unjustifiably.
So it eventually led to court cases and scandals about initiation by people that
associated themselves unjustly perhaps with the
organization. So Mathers went to Paris. He's
married to Henri Bergson's sister, who Yeats had
contact with as well. And Mathers sends Crowley to
London to retrieve documents in 1900. And Yeats
and the others don't want him to, they don't see
he's entitled to them. So we had what's sometimes
referred to as the Battle of Bligh Road in
Hammersmith, I think, where Crowley is coming
dressed up in magical garb to retrieve these
documents. He had been barred from the
headquarters, from the temple. And he comes,
and according to the stories, he's making chance,
magical chance, coming up the stairs. And Yeats is
there doing equivalent chance to keep him away.
And eventually he resorts, he kicks him down the
stairs, according to the story. And there's a
case that Crowley loses. And kicking him down
the stairs in Glasgow, they say, well, that's
magic. But that tension was there. And it continues.
There's another interesting connection. Of course,
Crowley gets the Book of the Law and Telema
through channeling. And this is what
subsequently Yeats does when he marries in 1917.
Georgia or George Hyde Lees, his wife, begins
to channel from divine instructors or spiritual
instructors to him. And this had happened in
relation to Crowley. So it was a, she may have
had the inspiration from that previous, previous
arrangement. But the Book of the Law in 1904,
for me, was anticipated to some extent, and it's
the feeling of it, by a story that Yeats wrote in
1897 called the Tables of the Law. And this was
about the inversion of the Ten Commandments into
a dark, a dark magical force. So I wonder whether
that antagonism contributed towards Crowley's
particular development. There may have been a
connection there. And there's another really
curious connection, which is difficult, difficult
to fathom. In 1916, the revolution happened.
And Yeats, as many were surprised that they had
gone ahead with the rebellion. Although when he
had, he had performed the play, Cattley in the
Hoolahan in 1902, Stephen Gwynne, the critic,
had said, well, if you put plays like this on,
you have to be prepared for people to go out and
shoot each other or be shot. He understood the
incendiary possibilities of the theatricality,
the magic of theatre, which is another form of
magic, a projection onto the public. So after 1916,
when Yeats writes, he waits a while to write it
because it was a very difficult period. He writes
a poem, Easter 1916, and he's asking himself
whether his words had sent people out to be shot.
So whether his play and his poems had inspired
these people, which no doubt some of them did,
to be involved in an uprising, which involved
a number of poets and the signatories
of the Proclamation of the Irish Republic. And furthermore, he had put Cú Chulainn,
the ancient Irish warrior, on the stage in his
plays. And again, this is a kind of invocation
or an evocation of a figure that they believed
was real ontologically. So he asks himself
in the poem whether Cú Chulainn was with Porrick
Pearce in the general post office, whether actually
he was there beside him, whether this figure
that he had magically helped to bring back
into the public consciousness was actually
embodied in the spiritual rebellion was part of it.
But stranger than that, in 1915 in New York,
and this is difficult to make sense of,
Alistair Crowley and a group of people went
out to the Statue of Liberty in a boat. They
weren't allowed to land. But the purpose of that
for Crowley was to proclaim an Irish Republic.
And he proclaimed an Irish Republic, which was reported in the New York Times.
And this was months before the actual
proclamation in Dublin. So it's a very strange
parallel, again, and the explanation for that,
we could take a long time. But it's, again,
a thing that people should think about the idea
that public policy or the public arena is a
theatrical context that to many extent, we live in
a soap opera, we live in a context of projections,
that image is the basis of magic. And yet,
we are open to images, to millions of images,
all the time. And they we believe they don't
influence us. Well, these people, the magicians
believe that they did. And not only that, they
believed, or they had a sense that magical
operations could constitute and contribute
towards public affairs. So it's quite remarkable.
One of Yeats' most important works is a vision.
And it's derived from the channeling that came
through his wife. And I understand, I've looked
at it, I can't say that it's easy for me to digest
that kind of material. But the idea seems to be that spirit guides of some sort,
working through his wife are giving him images to use in his poetry.
Yes, just to just as a precursor to that, in his essay in 1901 on magic, he provides
the simplest explanation for his magical
worldview. And what he says was, that there is a
great mind, that's a great consciousness, if you
like, but he calls it a great mind. And the great
mind has a great memory, which in which is
recorded the affairs, if you like, of history,
pre history, it's recorded in this great memory.
And you could say that he didn't say in this one,
but you could say that's associated the spirit
is mundi or the anima mundi. And we have a
mind and a memory, and our memory is linked to or
can be linked to this great memory and great mind.
So the link between the two is via the techniques
and operation of symbols. So he provides a
very distinct view. And now, also, that he said in
that essay, that minds can flow into each other.
So our minds can flow into the great mind knit
into us. And also that minds can communicate
with each other that can flow between each
other. So in that context, he provides a simple
explanation. So you, you have your mind, you have
your memory, the memory is also constituted by
ancient elements, it's it links in and it can
link into the, to the older, or the existing great
memory and great mind. So what the magician is
doing what the what the mystical person is doing
is, is establishing better communication with
those forces. Now into this, you could see
the daemon figure, or I think the figure that
the equivalent that Blake uses is the genius,
your poetic genius, the daemon could be the
conduit between those things, they could be the,
the means on which you communicate. He, one symbol
that's very important for Yeats is the idea of the
mask. So the mask becomes important, the rose
in the 1890s, and he moves on to the mask.
And the mask, we can trace that back through
the magical literature, through the ancient
literature, the mask is often used by a magician.
It's used for a number of purposes, not least if
they're engaging in astral travel so that they,
they will appear differently. But Yeats sees as
a deep, as a technique that enables you to develop your anti-self. So in many senses,
Yeats is a precursor of what Carl Jung later
writes about, and a lot of his interest in symbols,
his interest in masks, his interest in the equivalent to the anima and the animus,
it kind of anticipates a lot of what Jung is
doing. But instead of having the kind of dark
side and a dark self, Yeats has the anti-self,
which means different things in his complex
vision, but it often means the elements of you
that you don't have, the things that you need.
So instead of looking inside at your bad bits,
it's an idea that you can expand your good bits,
or you can accommodate all the things as far as
I can see. So the mask was often a device as well
to contact with your daemon. Now what the daemon
is varies. There's two different constructions,
at least we could put on it. We can, we can,
well, there's, there's a number, there's three.
One, we can see it as, as our subconscious or
as a, the collective unconscious or accessing
those elements in a Jungian sense. And if we go
back in the, as we've talked about before with
Suhrawardi and the Persian tradition and Corban,
we have the man of light, the person of light as
well, the double. Now Steiner says that in
the Council of Constantinople in 889, that the
Catholic church abolished the spirit. There used
to be a two-spirit doctrine. There was the soul
and there was the spirit. And he claims, it's
subject to interpretation, that that used to be
there in the early Christian tradition, but it
was taken away. So there's this idea that we have
our spiritual body as well. So the daemon could
be just that, but there is also the sense that the
daemon is the historical or could be historical
figures, figures that are attracted to you either
because sometimes because they're different from
you or they are instructors. So there's this idea
of instruction. There is a strong idea that comes
up in the literature and various contexts of a
cosmic classroom. People often experience this
when they're asleep. They feel like they're being
instructed and they come up with information that
they couldn't have had through other sources.
It's noetic kind of instruction. So what it is,
is unclear. All those possibilities are there, but
it's a muse, a source of inspiration. Sometimes
he's dealing with these instructors at a higher
level. Sometimes he's dealing with his daemon.
Sometimes he's dealing with particular spiritual
guides like Leo Africanus, who used to come
through in seances. He was very interested in
seances. He attended seances regularly and through that he had figures that came and
dialogued with him. Some of them particular figures and some of them important.
So from his simple explanation of magic, through
other works like as we talked about Swedenborg,
Essay, and also another work which is Per amica
silentia lunae, he comes to the vision in 1927.
By now he had won the Nobel Prize. So I think
in his head he probably thought he was a great
scientist as well. So he sets up a very
comprehensive and difficult system which revolves
around phases of the moon, 28 phases with
particular characteristics, highly astrologically
astute, which indicates patterns in the human
psyche in world history. He helps him to look at
the phases of world history to advocate a theory,
to suggest that we're coming to the end of an era,
that the Christian era is over, that history, the
psyche, the great mind works in accordance with
certain principles. One key symbol which has to
be mentioned is the gyre, or gyre if you like,
and this is if you like a spire, a cone, or a
spiral. This idea is important to remember if
you're ever reading his poetry. He had this idea
that a lot of the world can be explained by one
force which starts off and spirals and expands
to its utter outmost limits, and at the end
another figure spirals back. So there are natural
phases of things where they contract and expand
and contract and expand. So it's like the yin and
yang, it can work repeatedly like a DNA sequence,
it works in relation to cycles of history. It
can lead to a certain fatalistic view where you
believe something has expanded too much and it's
going to contract. So it ties in with some of the
ideas of Nietzsche, who had some influence on
him, and also to Spengler. But it's an interesting
idea that he uses, and it's also related to
a fundamental idea associated with the heart.
The heart is one of the recurrent symbols that
he has in his literature, and of course he's
referring to the physical heart, but more
importantly he's referring to the mystical heart,
even the sacred heart. The movement of the
heart, as we know in a lot of the traditions,
is consistent with the idea of the universe, that
we're moving from a contraction and expansion,
contraction and expansion, and the blood flowing
through it. So this idea of activity and repose,
activity and repose, is a fundamental idea, a
dual kind of interaction with some other substance
that appears in it. So the vision should be seen as a comprehensive development
with his cosmic instructors of his simpler
worldviews. But although a lot of people have
not made a lot of his comprehensive system, it may happen that it will be revisited and
reinterpreted and simplified for the future.
But it certainly draws on a lot of ancient
mystical literature, and there are insights that
one can come to in different ways. It's curiously
quasi-scientific or mechanistic in its worldview,
but what he meant by it was that we really had to
attune ourselves into the natural world, into
the cycles of the moon, into the subjective and
objective interactions. We saw the moon and
sun as having different functions, through our
connections with the planets and the universe.
So there's an element of a medieval worldview,
or a worldview that Paracelsus might have
recognized. Again, I think one should approach
the vision with a kind of open-minded, fluid
approach, and not get too hung up on it, but
look for the insights that are there. He used it
to provide a way to look at historical figures
or historical phases. It may provide insights
if one approaches it with a poetic looseness.
Well, I would imagine that for probably most
of our viewers, they've heard the name of
William Butler Yeats, but he's sort of one of those dusty old white male figures of
literary history. What is his relevance today?
What can we say about his influence on our lives?
That's no country for old men. A lot of the phrases we hear around us go back to Yeats.
People would be surprised at the extent to
which he's quoted. He's out of copyright now,
so it's easy for people to reproduce him. He's
been turned into songs. But what he is doing is
starting this tradition of recognition of the force of the technical society,
the technocratic society, the technological
society. He sees the deadly effect of modernism.
He becomes friendly with William Fletcher Barrett in Dublin, who had worked with John
Tyndall in his laboratory. He came to Dublin and
he engaged in your business in parapsychology
and investigation of paranormal activities and
psychical research. Yeats knew him. That was part
of a reaction to the overextensive claims of
science and imperial scientism. Yeats saw that
straight away. Through his wide, magical, poetic
view, what he's saying is that the imagination
is the most important thing. The imagination,
therefore, it fits in with the impetus and the
intent of the Inklings. It fits in with William
Blake, who he worked on. He published. He edited
William Blake's poems when he goes to London
when he was a young man. They discovered
some poems that had been forgotten about. He's
very important as a proponent of William Blake's
view. William Blake, of course, is the great
proponent of the imagination, as is Swedenborg.
He was also influenced by Burma. He was also very
influenced by the Greeks, by the Neoplatonists,
by Plato, by the pre-Socratic philosophers like Empedocles, who gave him some of the
ideas about the Gaia. What he provides is a
channel to a continuous pattern of resistance
against unduly narrow perception of the
world. In the book, Louis Lambert by Balzac,
the student who is obviously a representative
or reflection of Balzac himself,
he's bullied at school. They call him poet
and Pythagoras, which doesn't seem that bad.
They are referring to the fact that the boy was
getting interested in ancient Greek and a bigger
worldview. Yeats would have been interested in
that as well. He was influenced by Oscar Wilde
as well, who he knew. Through his activities,
anticipating the Inklings, he was involved in the
Reimers Club at the Old Cheshire Cheese in London.
He was trying to mobilize the artistic movements,
for example, of symbolism and decadence towards
his religion. What he's doing through his whole
life is saying that the ancient traditions are
relevant. They're fundamentally important to the
development of human consciousness. We have been fooled by the idea of what he called a
sentimentalist. He believed that a person who
lived in the sense world and didn't see anything
else was a sentimentalist, with the implication
there of an undue concentration on feeling to the
exclusion of anything else. We concentrate that
with, if you like, the poet or the person who
lived in reality. The person who engaged in the
real world with a capital R, they were engaging
in reality. The other people were misled. He
provides a choice to us. He provides and points
to an enchanted, meaningful world in contrast
to a nihilistic world dominated by scientism,
which leads to disenchantment and disillusionment.
Another person who didn't appreciate
Yeats to some extent was Samuel Beckett, although he came from the same class.
It strikes me that Samuel Beckett went through
psychoanalysis in the Tavistock Clinic near
Russell Square and met Jung early on. He had great
issues and portrays in many sense a nihilistic
worldview. When you come to compare the work of
William Butler Yeats to the work of Samuel Beckett,
who I like in other respects, but if you look at
Waiting for Godot, the more I think about it in
relation to where he came from, in relationship to
Yeats, is that Waiting for Godot is a representation
of his spiritual world in some senses. It has
curious resonances with the world that Yeats
described, equivalent to the Bardot play, that
the person who hasn't engaged with their spirit,
who hasn't engaged in the spiritual world, can
find themselves lost and a husk of themselves in
the next world, not knowing where they are.
As I was reading his descriptions recently of
the afterlife, he wrote a lot about moving on to the next plane and what happens,
which reminded me sometimes about Arthur, your
mentor Arthur M. Jung. There are some similarities
in relation to the description of descent into
being and escape, and there's right angles there
as well. To some extent, the vision presented by
Beckett is a bleak vision, which is meaningless,
with vague kind of humor in it. It mirrors what
Yeats is describing of the world of people who
are lost in the next dimension. It struck me very
forcefully when you look at some of the comments
by Beckett on the spiritual worldview and that
kind of existentialism in France that he was
mixed up in or had connections with, that really
he is describing a spiritual world as well,
and a spiritual world on the next plane. Why
he is relevant is he provides, through his deep
psychological explorations, a sense of what
Lewis would have called a deeper magic. It's
deeper than the dark magic. This is a magic
associated with knowing yourself on a deeper
level and about knowing, if you believe in
reincarnation, the incarnations you have been
in before, of getting access to the embedded
consciousness that is inscribed in your own
consciousness and making sense of the archetypes.
He has a whole range of symbols for archetypes,
from the fool, the beggar, the king, that appear
in his work, again, anticipating to some extent
the work of Jung. He provides in it a way of
looking at the world, a way of looking at yourself,
which is magnanimous and exploratory and
cosmopolitan. In it, he is capable of seeing
his relationships in a mythic way, for example.
His relationship with Maud Gonne, looking from
outside, he persists in asking in her hand for
marriage, even when it's clear she's not going
to marry him. He would see that in a mythic context, in relation to ancient legends,
in parallels in relation to ancient legends.
He would see connections with Mother Ireland,
with the goddess, whatever. You could see there's different levels to it.
Even with the dark side and the things that
didn't work out, he was able to transform them.
He was able to alchemically transmute them. He
begins to provide and indicate strategies of the
imagination to cope with daily life, to derive
meaning from daily life, to make sense of grand
events, to deal with grand events. His insights
provide deep psychological intuition that is
reflected in his poetry, that can speak to people
and probably speak in ways, because of their
focus on symbols, that transcend the particularity
of the context, if we open ourselves up to them.
He also provides a way, I've suggested and we've
talked about before, I think that in future,
to deal with the great forces of concentrated
technological development, that there will have
to be unity between the different traditions at a
higher level. He was open to learning from all the
different traditions and to integrating them and
to provide mechanisms and structures to be able to
respect them, as well as respecting the poetic
genius of all the particular peoples and looking
at them. He's extremely meaningful. There are
critics of him for his later stage, because of his
flirtation in the 30s or disposition to a kind
of quasi-fascism before he realized what it was.
One thing that is difficult to explain is his
interest in eugenics later on, but I think they
were mistaken directions. Nobody's perfect. It
does tie into some sense of elitism, which he
certainly had. He saw then that all the big
ideas, whether it was communism or fascism or an
over-dominant church, they would take away the
human imagination. Now, if you look at people
that have interpreted Yeats, like William Earvin
Thompson, who you've met, I believe, he talked
about, he was interested, he did a PhD in 1916
on the revolution. He spoke and wrote about the
vision, but he emphasized the need to be careful
about institutions and to reflect on the institution
of the individual. Yeats is emphasizing the power
and magnificence of the human imagination and the
institution of the individual. His father, in
fact, when he was asked about William Butler
Yeats' education, said that the most important
thing, and he used this word, was that he
developed his sovereignty. He actually used that
word about William Butler Yeats. That idea of
individual sovereignty, which fits into other
traditions, which doesn't dismiss the wisdom of
the past, which doesn't get so entranced with the
immediate and the moment that it forgets itself,
is an important part. He's deeply relevant.
People will find, if they flick through his work,
it's so available now, all the plays, all the
poems. Even if you're a pauper, you can get access
to William's poetry. Your mind can be a palace,
as they say. He's deeply relevant to people.
You'll find words or phrases, and some of these
have a hint of gold about them. They have a hint
of magic, of real magic about them. The real magic
that Jung talked about, about dug up from the dark
mud of the subconscious and brought to light so
the gold can be revealed. There's a lot of that,
a lot of ability to touch into ancient wisdom
across the traditions, bringing the best
from Kabbalah and Judaism and the history there,
and Christianity, and through his interest in
the Arab world. It's really a model that operates
on a worldwide context that I think he will remain
relevant over the next century.
I know he's had a big influence on my friend Whitley Strieber.
I remember he recited the poem when he talked to
you, and he did it very well. For him, it was a
key for him and his wife. It was a key context in
their life and afterwards. There is a parallel,
I think, some inspiration there in his life,
perhaps in the opening up of his consciousness
to the other worlds. Whitley Strieber as well
identifies the importance of that heritage,
which Kathleen Raine described it very well. She
was very interested, the poet, and she was very
interested in Yeats. She's talked about
Byzantium, which is the city of imagination that
Yeats sees, like Blake sees Jerusalem. She said
that she wasn't Irish, but she was part of the
Ireland of the imagination. As Ireland goes
through a massive transformation, I never thought
I'd see, towards materiality, towards a changing
from its ancient culture to a modern culture,
which is economically cosmopolitan, but rootless
in many senses, in two senses phonetically,
then that will be lost in many senses. What
will remain out of that and will be perhaps more
accessible in an international context is this
channeling of what was a holy and special place
through the Ireland of the imagination, whereby
the connections, I would feel, connections to
people who weren't from Ireland, who engaged in
the deep model that it provides in relation to
understanding the world, in relation to the similar thing, the universal imagination of
humankind. It doesn't matter. These figures show that it didn't matter whether it came
from Kabbalah, whether it came from the Arab world, whether it came from India,
that people who are open to universal truths can
present you with universal truths. You don't know
where they're going to come from. Whitley Strieber
subscribes, as far as I can see, to the Ireland of
the imagination. He is a living example of someone
where the poetry provides a very direct and
meaningful connection to his wife, as far as I remember, in a different space.
This revivifies the world by showing us that the
ghosts at the window pane, to describe another
thing that Yeats wrote about, or he saw the ghosts
in a double of humans on the breath when they're
having wine. Our world is enchanted with things
that we don't understand, but all the traditions
tell us that they exist. The people that have
maintained the integrity of the human imagination,
who have been open, I think point the way forward
to providing the contrary force to balance
the over-concentration, the left brain on technological society.
Well, I see right over your shoulder, our viewers who have been with us for the past
hour or more, have seen this image of Yeats
that you yourself have painted. I'm pretty sure,
since you're a poet yourself, you find inspiration as well in his poetry.
I do, absolutely. It's not only that, it's that
sometimes you have to concentrate on figures,
on their life, in order to get a sense of
themselves. I found that very useful when I'm
painting, for example. I reproduced Rembrandt's
self-portrait. When you do so, the figure can
actually come alive. You begin to notice things,
which is quite remarkable. For example, Rembrandt
noticed that he's cold, and he was in a cold
time. That led me on a particular path that comes
true when you're painting. The figures can come
true when you're doing that. It makes you think
about them or empathize with them. I was thinking
about Yeats as the young magician and what it
meant to him and what it was. Curiously, what
struck me when I was doing that was, when you
look at some of the older pictures, was the
resemblance between him and the face of Harry
Potter. The Harry Potter figure, who is the
modern magician for a lot of people with the round
glasses and the dark hair, of course, when they're
casting, they look back at models for what a

no evidence, but accidentally, consciously or
unconsciously, they seem to have produced a kind of reflection of the young Yeats.
I was asking myself, well, what image would be
coming to mind by him? The figure that came to
mind was an Irish figure called Monaghan MacLear, which is associated with the sea.
My sense was that there was something, he would have been preoccupied with something
associated with the sea. That was what, if you
like, came up. There was a representation of
that figure. Then recently, they were shown
pictures of nuclear weapons being detonated in
the west of Ireland and waves engulfing Ireland.
It prefigured, in a way, some of the senses that,
or some of the ancient stories. Colm Kyll talked about the sea in Ireland.
The symbols and figures are an active part of
your own imagination. You can look and say,
okay, that's him talking about his unrequited love
on the road. Really, the point of them being there
is so we can awaken our own consciousness about
these things, about look at what they meant by
a tree, for example. The power of the symbol of
the tree is remarkable, as we've seen in relation
to Tolkien, as we've seen in relation to Blake,
who talked about art being the tree of life and
science being the tree of death. That's for
him, the two trees. These things are relevant.
Looking at the lives of people who have focused on art, on contributing something,
on contributing meaning. The adherence and respect
for people who are endeavouring to help us with
meaning provides us with resources and resilience
that we all need in a world which seeks to demean
us, and to demean existence, and to reduce existence, and to dispirit us. Once you get
dispirited, or once you have meaning stripped
out of your consciousness, or once it's reduced,
or denied, or inflated, then it becomes difficult

joyfully engage in the world. Yes, I look at

so he knows he's not alone. It's identification

express their vulnerabilities, that express

the point was that as one gets older, the soul
sings more. It's not defined by its physicality.
It's an important point in relation to our

lot of the movement in the next life is to get

figures can be used, as he explained in relation
to symbols and as Jung would have explained,
to activate our consciousness, to activate our vision. Vision is a critical thing.
Even for William Fletcher Barrett, he made discoveries about the eye and developed a
machine to look at his own cataracts and examine

about on a higher level is the spiritual eyes,
the eyes that can see beyond, that can remote
viewing is another aspect involved. These are
all things that are inherent in the human consciousness. Yes, I would recommend that
if people are beginning to look at some of these
figures, they're referring to symbols that they
should actively engage with. You read the poem
about the rose, well, begin to understand that
this is a deep philosophical and mystical thing
that can actually operate in our consciousness,
not just on your mind, not just in compartmentalizing them in the left brain.
They can actually work as figures or symbols or
initiators. You talked about self-initiation.
Art in many senses is involved in the initiation
into a different worldview to break out of the
shell of the limitations of part of your brain
that seeks to particularly be influenced by the
external world that wants to project a limiting
view on human consciousness. I find those,
I find certain figures very inspirational and I
go back to them and I use them. I think that's
really the thing. You interact with them
and you play with the figures, you use them,
you reflect on them and you will get something
back because they were seeking to give something.
Well, in closing, James, is there a favorite poem
of Yeats that you would like to share with us?
I could recite a few poems, but I think in a lot of the poetry work, people
come back to a few recurrent poems and they

came to mind, I don't know why, but it was a
poem called The Two Trees. If you don't mind,
I'll read it to you. It comes in two parts just to
anticipate, it may be a bit useful. There's two
parts, there's a bright side and then a dark side.
And the trees, again, I've referred to what they may mean, but of course,
in The Golden Dawn and that, the tree of life
was there and the grades were associated with
rising up the sephirah and Yeats' vision was
of energy coming down through the sephirah,

I just wanted to think about the glass and gazing

symbol in time, I think the glass today refers
to the screen, to television, to mobile phones,
to the black mirror, to scrying, whatever. And
I really think it's relevant in that context.
So gazing at the glass, I think it was prophetic
in relation to just to think about it. And again,
it's a mystical thing. So there's different levels.
So he's talking about to his beloved, but the
beloved could be his, I see as his daughter
in this context. And I am struck. It's a thing that even in my lifetime, Jeffrey,
for young women, the way that technology and the
media have made young women and young men now
obsessed with their appearance in a very deleterious way. It's a kind of a crippling
thing associated with corporate desires to
sell products and marketing, but it's a deadly,
it's a deadly disease. And in this, all of these
again, and boys and girls are developing masks
to hide themselves. And really the important
thing is what's behind it is the tree of life
in them, the spiritual tree, their spiritual
capacity. And that's a context in which it comes.
Okay. It's called the two trees. Beloved gaze in
thine own heart. The holy tree is growing there
from joy, the holy branches start and all the
trembling flowers. They bear the changing colors
of its fruit have dowered the stars with Mary
light. The surety of its hidden root has planted
quiet in the night. The shaking of his lofty
head, leafy head has given the waves their melody
and made my lips and music wed murmuring a wizard
song for thee. There the loves a circle go,
the flaming circle of our days, gyrings spiring
to and fro in those great ignorant leafy ways.
Remembering all that shaken hair and how the winged sandals dart,
thine eyes grow full of tender care. Beloved gaze in thine own heart.
Gaze no more in the bitter glass. The demons with
their subtle guile lift up before us when they
pass or only gaze a little while. For there a
fatal image grows that the stormy night receives
roots half hidden under snows, broken boughs
and blackened leaves. For all things turn to
barrenness in the dim glass the demons hold. The
glass of outer weariness made when God slept in
times of old. There through the broken
branches go the ravens of unresting thought,
flying, crying to and fro, cruel claw and hungry
throat, or else they stand and sniff the wind and
shake their ragged wings. Alas thy tender eyes
grow all unkind. Gaze no more in the bitter glass.
James Tenney, once again, a very thought-provoking
and delightful conversation. It's been an enormous
pleasure to be with you and to probe into the life of this very seminal poet.
Again, thank you for the opportunity. Thank you
for your inputs and your contributions to this

for your work in bringing some of these figures

be able to share you with the New Thinking
Allowed audience, James. Thank you so much
for being with me today. Thank you, Jeffrey.
And for those of you listening or watching, thank you for being with us.
